results.title: Animated motion. Pt. 4
results.creator_credit: Grant Munro, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this fourth film, Norman McLaren explains and illustrates composite motion, where two of the categories of motion occur simultaneously in one action, as are the motions of jointed or pivoted parts (as occur in animal and human movements). Also shown is a human gesture with increasing amounts of emotion; and finally, the phenomenon of “strobing” in animation is examined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Grant Munro, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Animated motion. Pt. 2
results.creator_credit: Grant Munro, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this second film, Norman McLaren presents the first three of the five categories of motion: constant, accelerated, and decelerated. Various types of acceleration and deceleration are demonstrated, and examples are shown of how these types of motion may be applied in regard to gesture, gravity, and perspective.

results.title: Animated genesis (TEFC)
results.brief_description: An allegory of the creation of the world, of man’s enslavement by the machine, motivated by Greed, which is personified as an enormous and menacing spider. It is eventually overthrown by the intervention of Goodness, but not before atomic warfare has resulted. The Foldes made the film at home, drawing all 32,000 pictures, and showed the 16mm result to Sir Alexander Korda, who had it blown up to 35mm for theatrical release. No other credits available.

results.title: Animals: friends or food? [Widescreen] (D)
results.creator_credit: Jason Young, Kent Martin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A would-be farmer, Jason Young, and his partner take on an abandoned farm property, with the view to running a small hobby-farm, and horse-riding school. Whilst Julia attends to the horse-business Jason decides to experiment with raising an array of animals with a view to eating them, in order to bring himself closer to the processes of animal husbandry that so many have become immune to. Thus begins Jason’s year of discovery as he buys, bonds, feeds, tends and lovingly breeds the animals. At certain points when Jason is called upon to slaughter the animals he confronts the issues around meat eating, and is moved by the bonds he has formed with the various breeds. Although at times simplistic, this documentary nevertheless teases out the issues of the meat consumer industry, human-animal relationships and the ethical treatment of animals. Contains scenes of animal slaughter. Please note: some scenes may disturb.

results.title: Animals of the Arctic
results.creator_credit: Stephen Maslowski, Karl Maslowski and Centron Films
results.brief_description: This film introduces students to the wide variety of wildlife that roams the plains and seashores of the Arctic. It shows how the animals and birds have adapted to their environment. Photography: Karl and Stephen Maslowski. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Animal Crackers
results.brief_description: This is one of the Marx Brothers’ funniest films, with Groucho starring as the big, wild, game hunter causing more delirium in high society than in the jungle! A painting is stolen in a high society home, and the Marx Brothers are there to lend their confusing hand to solve the crime.

results.title: Angus lost
results.creator_credit: Gary Templeton, John Sturner, Firehouse Productions and Evergreen Productions
results.brief_description: Angus is a very curious, clever Scottish terrier, whose curiosity gets him into a number of close scrapes. This is a live-action, non-verbal adaptation of Marjorie Flack’s classic book and is sure to delight audiences both young and old.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gary Templeton, John Sturner, Firehouse Productions and Evergreen Productions

results.title: Angus
results.creator_credit: Andy Thomson, Michael Scott, William Canning and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film portrait of Angus Mowat, with commentary by his son, author Farley Mowat. At 76, Angus still shows an enviable capacity for life, turning his hand to things that the leisure of retirement now makes possible. One of these is the rebuilding of an old fishing boat, converting it to sail. This is a picture of a man who has reached his later years with no slackening of interest in life, who finds a good and constant companion in nature, and contentment in the quiet isolation of his cabin by the shore.

results.title: Angotee: story of an eskimo boy
results.creator_credit: Douglas Wilkinson, Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The time is 1953 and the place is the eastern Arctic. Beginning with a scene in an igloo showing the birth of Angotee to Atootoo, wife of the hunter Koonuk, this film follows the events of a man’s growth from birth to maturity. During babyhood Angotee is secure in the protection of his mother. His childhood is free and happy as he plays games invented out of the skills he will need as a man. During adolescence he accompanies his father on the hunt and enters the company of men where he shoots his first seal. The story ends as Angotee leaves the parental igloo to set up his own abode as a family man and a hunter of the great snow-swept barrens. Awards: Durban; Trento; Toronto.

results.title: Angkor, the lost city
results.creator_credit: Roger Blais and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Angkor - a whole metropolis of palaces and temples recovered from the jungle which hid them for centuries until discovered in 1860 by a French naturalist. Monuments, picture tapestries in stone and Angkor Vat, a mile square temple of grey sandstone which no other church has rivalled in size, reveal the glories of the past empire of the Khmers, ancestors of the Cambodians.
